review.title: Organic Computing in the Spotlight
review.abstract: Organic Computing is an initiative in the field of systems engineering that proposed to make use of concepts such as self-adaptation and self-organisation to increase the robustness of technical systems. Based on the observation that traditional design and operation concepts reach their limits, transferring more autonomy to the systems themselves should result in a reduction of complexity for users, administrators, and developers. However, there seems to be a need for an updated definition of the term "Organic Computing", of desired properties of technical, organic systems, and the objectives of the Organic Computing initiative. With this article, we will address these points.

metadata.title: Organic Computing in the Spotlight

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Within the last decade, we have seen dramatic changes, from isolated to highly interconnected and increasingly autonomous systems, in response to the observation that traditional engineering and control concepts are reaching their limits.

sections.heading: 2 Term Definition
sections.text: Organic computing is based on the realization that we are increasingly surrounded by large collections of autonomous systems, equipped with sensors and actors who are aware of their environment, freely communicate and organize themselves in order to carry out the actions and services that seem necessary. Consequently, we define the term "organic computing" (OC) as follows: an "organic computing system" (or just an organic system) is a technical system equipped with sensors (to perceive its environment) and actuators (to manipulate it); it adapts autonomously and dynamically to the current conditions of the perceived environment. This adaptation process has an impact on the usability of the organic system, which is continuously improved by the organic system itself. To enable such adaptive behavior, it employs so-called self-mechanisms that affect it.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this article, we briefly summarized the historical development in the context of the Organic Computing Initiative. Organic Computing is a systems engineering initiative that proposed to use concepts such as self-adaptation and self-organization to enhance the robustness of technical systems. As - at least from our point of view - there is no precise and universally accepted concept of the term in the literature, we derived a specification of the concept and the underlying objectives of the initiative from the transfer of more autonomy to the systems themselves and supplemented it with an explanation of the main characteristics of OC systems. Finally, future development options of OC were outlined.

Within the last decade, information and communication technology (ICT) has witnessed a dramatic change: from isolated manually controlled systems to highly interconnected and increasingly autonomous systems [1,2].
In order to provide mechanisms to cope with these complexity challenges, initiatives such as Organic Computing [3] have been proposed.

Such a new paradigm should enable future ICT systems to carry out certain tasks on their own, they should have properties such as self-organisation, self-healing, self-configuration, self-protection, self-optimisation, and they should be able to adapt reasonably to changing requirements of their operating environment [4].
